My dear Rosamond, it is not a question of choice.  We have begun too

this.  It is my fault: I ought to have known better, and I dese

I find, now I look into things a little, Rosy, that it is wonderful
what an amount of money slips away in our housekeeping.  I suppose the
servants are careless, and we have had a great many people co

Yes, they have bad taste in everything—they make economy look ugly.
We needn't do that.  I only meant that they avoid expenses, although
Wrench has a capital practice.

What I am to do in my practice, Rosy, it is for me to judge.  That is
not the question between us.  It is enough for you to know that our

It was understood from the beginning that my services would be

I am very sorry, Rosamond; I know this is painful.

I explained it to you at the time, dear.  That was only a security and

it's not a
question of liking.  Of course, I don't like it; it's the only thing I

To do what?  What is the use of my leaving my work in Middlemarch to

Well, then, if you will have it so, I do like it.
I admit that I like it better than making a fool of myself by going to

She will never love me much,
No,

but I shall call on him as I go by this morning.
No time must be lost.

If she will be happy and I can rub through, what does it all

How do you know?

Perhaps some one else may turn up.  I told Trumbull to be on the

What disagreeable people?

And suppose I disregard your opinion as you disregard mine?
These would be very strong considerations,

No, no,

I have nothing particular to say to him.
But—the game is up—I must be going—I came in just to see Bambridge.

talk;

No; if I were talking to him, I could
make a retreat before any signs of disinclination.

Would any man buy the practice of me even now, for as

One sees how any mental strain, however slight, may affect a delicate
frame,

by the deep stamp which
anxiety will make for a time even on the young and vigorous.  I am
naturally very strong; yet I have been thoroughly shaken lately by an
accumulation of trouble.

You have at all events taken your share in using good practical
precautions for the town, and that is the best mode of asking for
protection,

The town has done well in the way of cleansing, and finding
appliances; and I think that if the cholera should come, even our
enemies will admit that the arrangements in the Hospital are a public
good
Oh yes,
He has perhaps been losing a good deal of money.
The loss to the Hospital can hardly be made up, I fear.
No doubt that is a good device as to ways and means,

But I can't be expected to rejoice
in it at once, since one of the first results will be that the other

What did Mrs. Casaubon say?

If Mrs. Casaubon would take your place,
there would be gain, instead of loss.

I suppose,
then, that I may enter into the subject with Mrs. Casaubon.
I am much obliged to you for giving me full notice,

The highest object to me is
my profession, and I had identified the Hospital with the best use I

I have slipped into money difficulties which I can see no way out of,

occupied you too long.  Good-day.

I should think that is hardly necessary,

tame and terrified enough.  He might become more unmanageable.  But

Very well.  Then I need give my directions only to you,

Unless there turn out to be further complications, such as I have not

Do as you like,

broken, and that may make things easier to you.
The symptoms are worse.

No; I still think he may come round.  Are you going to stay here

From what I see of the case,

narcotism is the only thing I
should be much afraid of.  He may wear through even without much food.

Yes, I am,
No, thank you,

I mentioned to you

Yes,

that would pay all my debts, and leave me a little on
hand.  I could set about economizing in our way of living.  And

I am deeply obliged to you,

You have restored to me
the prospect of working with some happiness and some chance of good.
When did this change begin?
It's all over.

I think I know what you mean.  You had heard that there was an
execution in the house?
It was true,

But the danger is over; the debt
is paid.  I am out of my difficulties now: I shall be freed from debts,

Thank you for coming,

I can enjoy the
kindness all the more because I am happier.  I have certainly been a

feel that the torture-screw is off.
I don't believe you will ask anything that ought to offend me.
No,

Can I speak to you a moment?

Farebrother has just sent up a message to say that he wants to speak

You are losing confoundedly, and are making everybody stare

Bambridge is over there, but he is making a row—I don't think he's

So did I,
But he said that he went to see Bambridge.

Yes,
he was.  But I suppose it was an accidental thing.  I have never seen

Oh, about five or six times.
Yes.  You know all about it,
I made a clean breast to you.
I am under the deepest obligation to you, Mr. Farebrother,
I have not made any bets,
I could not be expected to give her up,

I will try to be worthy,
of you as well as of her.
I shall never forget what you have done,

I can't say
anything that seems worth saying—only I will try that your goodness

It certainly would have been a fine thing

R.text:
Yes, the life of a medical man is very arduous: especially when he is
so devoted to his profession as Mr. Lydgate is,
Of course you can dismiss the other two servants, if you like,

but I should have thought it would be very injurious to your
position for us to live in a poor way.  You must expect your practice
to be lowered.
Oh, if you think of living as the Wrenches do!

But I have heard you express your disgust at
that way of living.

Why should not you have a good practice, Tertius?  Mr. Peacock had.
You should be more careful not to offend people, and you should send
out medicines as the others do.  I am sure you began well, and

My uncle Bulstrode ought to allow you a salary for the time you
give to the Hospital: it is not right that you should work for nothing.
I thought, at least, when I had borne to send the plate back and have that man taking an inventory of the furniture—I should have thought that would suffice.
I never could have believed that you would like to act in that way.
I should have thought there were many other means than that,
Let us have a sale and leave Middlemarch altogether.

If we are to be in that position it will be entirely your own doing,
Tertius,

You will not behave as you ought to do to your own
family.  You offended Captain Lydgate.  Sir Godwin was very kind to me
when we were at Quallingham, and I am sure if you showed proper regard
to him
Have you spoken to Trumbull yet?
I have always thought her very agreeable,
I am sure he is a very deserving, well-principled young man,
Oh dear, yes; appearances have very little to do with happiness,

I think there is every prospect of their being a happy
couple.  What house will they take?
I should think it is a nice house; I like St. Peter's Place.
Oh no; I hear so little of those things.

indeed, if it had not been, she would not have wished to act on

Mr. Ned Plymdale has taken a house already.

I called at Mrs. Plymdale's this morning, and she told me that he had
taken the house in St. Peter's Place, next to Mr. Hackbutt's.
How much money is it that those disagreeable people want?

Those who took the list—and the others.  I mean, how much money would

But I mean how much should you want if we stayed in this house?

It is not necessary for you to tell me again,

I remembered what
you said.  You spoke just as violently as you do now.  But that does

for you.

hard to be disgraced here among all the people we know, and to live in

Certainly,

This is sudden, Mr. Garth,

reason for giving up a connection which I think I may say will be

MB.text:
I am going round to see
Mrs. Casaubon.  She was to come back from Yorkshire last night.  She
will like to see me, you know.

we have been hearing bad news—bad
news, you know.

descriptions.D: as informed me that though she has destined the chief part of those funds to another purpose, she is willing to consider whether she cannot fully take my place in relation to the Hospital. But she wishes for ample time to mature her thoughts on the subject, and I have told her that there is no need for haste—that, in fact, my own plans are not yet absolute. Lydgate was ready to say, If Mrs. Casaubon would take your place, there would be gain, instead of loss. But there was still a weight on his
descriptions.B: to consult Lydgate without delay on that particular morning, although he had nothing to tell beyond what he had told before. He listened eagerly to what Lydgate had to say in dissipation of his fears, though this too was only repetition; and this moment in which Bulstrode was receiving a medical opinion with a sense of comfort, seemed to make the communication of a personal need to him easier than it had been in Lydgate's contemplation beforehand. He had been insisting that it would be well for
descriptions.Lyd: casm, and there the subject was dropped. This was not the first time that Mr. Farebrother had heard hints of Lydgate's expenses being obviously too great to be met by his practice, but he thought it not unlikely that there were resources or expectations which excused the large outlay at the time of Lydgate's marriage, and which might hinder any bad consequences from the disappointment in his practice. One evening, when he took the pains to go to Middlemarch on purpose to have a chat with Lydgate
descriptions.R: ence of that interest in her husband's presence which a loving wife is sure to betray, even if etiquette keeps her aloof from him. When Lydgate was taking part in the conversation, she never looked towards him any more than if she had been a sculptured Psyche modelled to look another way: and when, after being called out for an hour or two, he re-entered the room, she seemed unconscious of the fact, which eighteen months before would have had the effect of a numeral before ciphers. descriptions.M: r family were present; the Vincy children all dined at the table, and Fred had persuaded his mother that if she did not invite Mary Garth, the Farebrothers would regard it as a slight to themselves, Mary being their particular friend. Mary came, and Fred was in high spirits, though his enjoyment was of a checkered kind—triumph that his mother should see Mary's importance with the chief personages in the party being much streaked with jealousy when Mr. Farebrother sat down by her. Fred used to be
descriptions.F: ut any difficulty there was a friendly ear ready. The opportunity came at Mr. Vincy's, where, on New Year's Day, there was a party, to which Mr. Farebrother was irresistibly invited, on the plea that he must not forsake his old friends on the first new year of his being a greater man, and Rector as well as Vicar. And this party was thoroughly friendly: all the ladies of the Farebrother family were present; the Vincy children all dined at the table, and Fred had persuaded his mother that if she d
descriptions.MB: iation of himself with Bulstrode, of which he now saw the full meaning as it must have presented itself to other minds. He now felt the conviction that this man who was leaning tremblingly on his arm, had given him the thousand pounds as a bribe, and that somehow the treatment of Raffles had been tampered with from an evil motive. The inferences were closely linked enough; the town knew of the loan, believed it to be a bribe, and believed that he took it as a bribe. Poor Lydgate, his mind strugg
descriptions.MrsV: ptured Psyche modelled to look another way: and when, after being called out for an hour or two, he re-entered the room, she seemed unconscious of the fact, which eighteen months before would have had the effect of a numeral before ciphers. In reality, however, she was intensely aware of Lydgate's voice and movements; and her pretty good-tempered air of unconsciousness was a studied negation by which she satisfied her inward opposition to him without compromise of propriety.
